- Add `@media print` CSS rules for consistent page breaks.  
  - Use `page-break-inside: avoid;` on: patient details, section headers + content, and tables.  
  - Apply `page-break-before/after` for large sections (e.g., Treatment Summary, Prescription Details).  
  - Wrap related elements (e.g., prescription header + medicines list) in containers.  
  - Test printing across major browsers (Chrome, Edge, Safari).

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#12643
activity.text:
I’ve tested this in both Windows and Linux environments and confirmed that the issue is indeed related to path resolution differences between platforms.

It’s not OS-specific behavior, but rather a result of using hardcoded paths instead of platform-agnostic resolution.

Using path.resolve or path.posix normalizes the file path, resolving the issue cleanly across both environments.

If you're okay with it, I’d be happy to create a PR to fix this — it would improve cross-platform compatibility for all contributors.

Let me know if I can proceed.

activity.title: ohcnetwork/care_fe#12643
activity.text:
Thanks for the follow-up! 
The error occurs because vite-plugin-static-copy expects pdf.worker.min.mjs to exist under:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/14a6699a-cec4-41f8-969d-aea5de29aa19)

This file may not exist in dev builds or when pdfjs-dist version changes .The plugin fails silently if the file isn’t found, leading to runtime PDF preview issues

The backend (running via Docker) is irrelevant in this failure — it doesn't serve the worker or static files.
So even if minio or other backends are up, this issue still occurs due to frontend worker misconfiguration. 

You can reproduce the error as specified in  video :
https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ebbb8ff4-37f5-4dab-aa3f-6294489c0a80
